arguments.claim: In partnership, prosecution must prove special agreement entrusting dominion over partnership assets to accused partner

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, as rightly pointed out by Harris J., the prosecution must establish that dominion over the assets or a particular asset of the partnership was, by a special agreement between the parties, entrusted to the accused person.

holdings.text: It seems to us that the view taken in Bhuban Mohan Ranas case by the later Full Bench of the Calcutta High Court is the right one.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the view taken in Bhuban Mohan Ranas case 1  by the later Full Bench of the Calcutta High Court is the right one. Upon the plain reading of s. 405, I.P.C. it is obvious that before a person can be said to have companymitted criminal breach

holdings.reasoning_summary: Endorses Full Bench decision that partner cannot be charged under analogous s.406 IPC for partnership property without fiduciary entrustment; applies to s.409.

holdings.text: Upon the plain reading of s. 405, I.P.C. it is obvious that before a person can be said to have committed criminal breach of trust it must be established that he was either entrusted with property or entrusted with dominion over property which he is said to have converted to his own use or disposed of in violation of any direction of law etc.

anchor.surface_text: Upon the plain reading of s. 405, I.P.C. it is obvious that before a person can be said to have committed criminal breach of trust it must be established that he was either entrusted with or entrusted with dominion over propery which he is said to have companyverted to his own use or disposed of in violation of any direction of law etc.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory interpretation requires entrustment or dominion resulting from entrustment for criminal breach of trust under s.405 IPC.

holdings.text: Every partner has dominion over property by reason of the fact that he is a partner. This is a kind of dominion which every owner of property has over his property. But it is not dominion of this kind which satisfies the requirements of s. 405.

anchor.surface_text: Every partner has dominion over property by reason of the fact that he is a partner. This is a kind of dominion which every owner of property has over his property. But it is number dominion of this kind which satisfies the requirements of s. 405. In order to establish entrustment of dominion over property to an accused person the mere existence of that persons dominion over property is number enough.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Partnership dominion akin to ownership does not constitute entrustment required under s.405 IPC.

holdings.text: the prosecution must establish that dominion over the assets or a particular asset of the partnership was, by a special agreement between the parties, entrusted to the accused person.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, as rightly pointed out by Harris J., the prosecution must establish that dominion over the assets or a particular asset of the partnership was, by a special agreement between the parties, entrusted to the accused person. If in the absence of such a special agreement a partner receives money belonging to the partnership

holdings.reasoning_summary: In partnership cases, special agreement needed to prove entrustment of dominion over partnership property.

holdings.text: In our opinion, therefore, the appellant cannot be said to be guilty of criminal breach of trust even with respect to the dues realised by him from Kablasingh and in not depositing them in the bank as alleged by the prosecution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No entrustment even for specific recovery mentioned in minutes; no obligation to deposit if needed for business.

holdings.text: It is obvious that an owner of property, in whichever way he uses his property and with whatever intention will not be liable for misappropriation and that would be so even if he is not the exclusive owner thereof. As already stated, a partner has undefined ownership along with the other partners over all the assets of the partnership.

anchor.surface_text: It is obvious that an owner of property, in whichever way he uses his property and with whatever intention will number be liable for misappropriaion and that would be so even if he is number the exclusive owner thereof. As already stated, a partner has, undefined ownership along with the other partners over all the assets of the, part- nership.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Partner's co-ownership precludes dishonest misappropriation under s.403 IPC of partnership property.

anchor.surface_text: In support of this contention reliance is placed upon Bhuban Mohan Rana Surendra Mohan Das 1 . There the following question was referred for decision by the Full Bench Can a charge under s. 406 of the Indian Penal Code be framed against a person, who, according to the complainant, is a partner with him and is accused of the offence in respect of property belonging to both of them as partners ?

precedents.case_name: Bhuban Mohan Rana v. Surendra Mohan Das
precedents.cited_proposition: A partner cannot be charged under s. 406 IPC for offence in respect of partnership property as no entrustment in fiduciary capacity and no distinct share until accounts taken
precedents.cited_holding: All five judges answered in the negative: partner does not hold partnership property in fiduciary capacity

precedents.citation: The Queen v. Okhoy Coomar Shaw 1 13 Bengal Law Reports 307

anchor.surface_text: Referring to the decision in The Queen v. Okhoy Coomar Shaw 1 in which a Full Bench had held that a partner who dishonestly misappropriates or converts to his own use any of the partnership property with which he is entrusted or over which he has dominion, is guilty of an offence under s. 405, P.C., Harris C.J. observed

precedents.cited_proposition: Partner who dishonestly misappropriates partnership property is guilty under s. 405 IPC
precedents.cited_holding: a partner who dishonestly misappropriates or converts to his own use any of the partnership property with which he is entrusted or over which he has dominion, is guilty of an offence under s. 405, P.C.

precedents.citation: Jagannath Raghunathdas v. Emperor 2 A. I. R. 1932 Bom. 47

anchor.surface_text: One of those cases was Jagannath Raghunathdas v. Emperor 2 where it was held that a partner may be prosecuted under s. 406, I.P.C. for failure to account for partnership monies and assets. In that case the partner who was the accused was given authority by the other partners to collect monies or property

precedents.cited_proposition: Partner given authority to collect partnership monies can be prosecuted under s. 406 IPC for failure to account if entrusted with dominion
precedents.cited_holding: a partner may be prosecuted under s. 406, I.P.C. for failure to account for partnership monies and assets where given authority to collect

precedents.citation: Bhuban Mohan Ranas case 1 I.L.R. 1962 11 Cal. 23.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the view taken in Bhuban Mohan Ranas case 1 by the later Full Bench of the Calcutta High Court is the right one. Upon the plain reading of s. 405, I.P.C. it is obvious that before a person can be said to have committed criminal breach of trust it must be established that he was either entrusted with or entrusted with dominion over propery

precedents.case_name: Bhuban Mohan Rana v. Surendra Mohan Das
precedents.cited_proposition: Partner has dominion over partnership property as owner, not by entrustment; requires special agreement for fiduciary entrustment
precedents.cited_holding: the prosecution must establish that dominion over the assets or a particular asset of the partnership was, by a special agreement between the parties, entrusted to the accused person

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chatterjee finally contends that the act of the appellant will at least amount to dishonest misappropriation of property even though it may number amount to criminal breach of trust and, therefore, his companyviction companyld be altered from one under s. 409 to that under s. 403. Section 403 runs thus Whoever dishonestly misappropriates or companyverts to his own use any moveable property, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both. It is obvious that an owner of property, in whichever way he uses his property and with whatever intention will number be liable for misappropriaion and that would be so even if he is number the exclusive owner thereof. As already stated, a partner has, undefined ownership along with the other partners over all the assets of the, part- nership. If he chooses to use any of them for his own purposes he may be accountable civilly to the other partners. But he does number thereby companymit any misappropriation. Mr. Chatterjees alternative companytention must be rejected.

outcome.relief_summary: Appellant not guilty of criminal breach of trust under s.409 IPC due to lack of entrustment; no dishonest misappropriation under s.403 IPC as partner has dominion as owner

Mr. Chatterjee finally contends that the act of the appellant will at least amount to dishonest misappropriation of property even though it may number amount to criminal breach of trust and, therefore, his companyviction companyld be altered from one under s. 409 to that under s. 403. Section 403 runs thus Whoever dishonestly misappropriates or companyverts to his own use any moveable property, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both. It is obvious that an owner of property, in whichever way he uses his property and with whatever intention will number be liable for misappropriaion and that would be so even if he is number the exclusive owner thereof. As already stated, a partner has, undefined ownership along with the other partners over all the assets of the, part- nership. If he chooses to use any of them for his own purposes he may be accountable civilly to the other partners. But he does number thereby companymit any misappropriation. Mr. Chatterjees alternative companytention must be rejected.

anchor.surface_text: Every partner has dominion over property by reason of the fact that he is a partner. This is a kind of dominion which every owner of property has over his property. But it is number dominion of this kind which satisfies the requirements of s. 405. In order to establish entrustment of dominion over property to an accused person the mere existence of that persons dominion over property is number enough.
